en.title:
Mighty Force Knights
<size=30>Newton's Law 1 and 2</size>
en.confirmDesc: Are you sure you want to restart the level?
en.credits_detail:
Written by: David Dionisio
Music from: Kevin MacLeod
en.newton_first_law_desc: Newton's first law states that an object at rest will remain at rest, and an object in motion will maintain a constant velocity unless acted upon by a net external force.
en.newton_first_law_dlg_1: A net external force is the sum of all forces acting on the object. If the net external force is zero, then there is no acceleration.
en.newton_first_law_dlg_1_2: I will now drop a large object from the sky to demonstrate.
en.newton_first_law_dlg_2: There are two forces currently acting on this object: gravity and normal force.
en.newton_first_law_dlg_3: The gravity force is pulling the object towards Earth, which allows it to fall in the first place.
en.newton_first_law_dlg_3_2: The normal force is pushing the object outwards from the surface.
en.newton_first_law_dlg_4: Adding both the gravity and normal force will result in zero net force. Thus, the object is at rest.
en.newton_first_law_dlg_5: It looks like the princess has been taken hostage by these nefarious goblins!
en.newton_first_law_dlg_6: Let us summon our mighty knights for a daring rescue!
en.newton_first_law_inertia_dlg_1: Excellent! Notice how it took a couple of knights to push the block?
en.newton_first_law_inertia_dlg_2: The block's mass allows its frictional force to resist the pushing force of the knights.
en.newton_first_law_inertia_dlg_3: Mass is a measure of inertia. The unit of measurement shown here is in kg (kilograms), which is 1000 grams per 1 kilogram.
en.newton_first_law_inertia_dlg_4: Inertia is the tendency of any physical object to resist any change in motion. A change in motion is acceleration due to net force acting on the object.
en.newton_first_law_inertia_dlg_5: I will now drop another object from the sky. This time with less mass. Just one more block to rescue our damsel in distress!
en.newton_first_law_inertia_2_dlg_1: In this scenario, we will learn more about how inertia influences force.
en.newton_first_law_inertia_2_dlg_2: Observe how the forces are interacting on this balance scale.
en.newton_first_law_inertia_2_dlg_3: The weight on each platform causes the scale to tip. If both platforms have equal weight, they will align horizontally.
en.newton_first_law_inertia_2_dlg_4: Here's a locked treasure as a demonstration. Put the correct amount of weight on the other platform to unlock it.
en.newton_first_law_inertia_2_victory: You have opened the treasure chest! Behold, the riches uncovered:
en.dragWeightsHelp: Drag these weights on top of the platform.
en.newton_second_law_desc: Newton's second law states that the acceleration of an object is proportional to the net force acting on it, and inversely proportional to its mass.
en.dragForceSlider: Drag the slider to change the Force value.
en.newton_second_law_dlg_1: Acceleration is what causes an object’s velocity to change over time. Which means the object will speed up, slow down, or change direction.
en.newton_second_law_dlg_2: Here are the equations for both the net force (F-net), and acceleration (A). Where mass is kilograms (kg), distance is meters (m), and time is seconds (s).
en.newton_second_law_dlg_3: As you can see, the more mass an object has, the less it will accelerate from the net force.
en.newton_second_law_dlg_4: Note that: force, acceleration, and velocity are all vectors.
en.newton_second_law_dlg_4_2: A vector is composed of a value for each axis. In this case, the x and y. These values can also tell us the direction, and the magnitude.
en.newton_second_law_dlg_5: A mighty knight has brought us a wheel to demonstrate. The wheel is enchanted with magical trails to allow us to observe its motion.
en.newton_second_law_dlg_6: The first few trails are where the knight was pushing the wheel. You can see that the distance between them are increasing.
en.newton_second_law_dlg_7: At this point, the distance between each trail is equal. This means that the net force acting on the wheel is zero.
en.newton_second_law_dlg_8: The trails here are going down. We can observe that the only force acting on the wheel is gravity.
en.newton_second_law_graph_1: The graph maps out the trails across time along the x and y axis. Be sure to check the velocity and acceleration by scrolling down.
en.newton_second_law_graph_2: Observe how the position line curves as velocity increases, indicating that there is acceleration.
en.newton_second_law_graph_3: If the position line is straight, then velocity is constant, and therefore no acceleration.
en.newton_second_law_dlg_9: The nefarious goblins have appeared out of thin air! They are surely up to no good. Push them off the cliff with the wheel.
en.pressToProceed: Press this button when you are ready to continue.
en.dragAngleHelp: Drag this to adjust the cannon's angle.
en.graphReminder: Remember to check the graph to analyze the trajectory of the cannonball.
en.newton_second_law_2_dlg_3: Let us bring forth the mighty cannon to vanquish these vermin!
en.newton_second_law_2_dlg_5: As you fire away, observe that the projectile will move at a constant velocity along the X-axis.
en.dragForcePushHelp: Drag the Force Field to this surface.
en.dragForceAdjustHelp: You can reposition a Force Field by dragging it.
en.playButtonHelp: Press this button to start the simulation.
en.trashButtonHelp: Press and hold the trash button to clear out the Force Fields.
en.act_2_end_dlg_1: A large meteorite is approaching Earth! Total destruction awaits us if nothing is done!
en.act_2_end_dlg_2: Seek the golden ball, for it will grant you the force to thwart the impending doom.
